The town received its name based on its origins as a socialist commune in the early 1900sâ€”. Literally, in the eyes of its founders, the land of the town was to be free for all people. Some of the first settlers were veterans of a prior experiment in socialism, the nearby Equality Colony.

value: content=A free, scheduled bus services the island, from
north with connections to Mt. Vernon on the mainland, with Island Transit. The bus operates daily except Sundays, with reduced trips on Saturdays.
content=provides transportation service between communities on Whidbey and Sea-Tac Airport.
File:Giant cedar in South Whidbey State Park.JPG
Giant cedar in South Whidbey State Park

Double Bluff Beach Access and Double Bluff State Park is a popular beach on the Southend of Whidbey Island with its offering of shellfish harvest and at times total solitude along the shores of Useless Bay, Admiralty Inlet, and Double Bluff to the North of the Puget Sound.

South Whidbey State Park provides both beach access and forested trails through a mixture of second growth and old growth timber.
